Optimal Algorithms for Online Convex Optimization with Adversarial Constraints

Abhishek Sinha, Rahul Vaze
School of Technology and Computer Science
Tata Institute of Fundamental Research
Mumbai 400005, India
abhishek.sinha@tifr.res.in, rahul.vaze@gmail.com
Abstract

A well-studied generalization of the standard online convex optimization (OCO) framework is constrained online convex optimization (COCO). In COCO, on every round, a convex cost function and a convex constraint function are revealed to the learner after it chooses the action for that round. The objective is to design an online learning policy that simultaneously achieves a small regret while ensuring a small cumulative constraint violation (CCV) against an adaptive adversary interacting over a horizon of length Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. A long-standing open question in COCO is whether an online policy can simultaneously achieve Oâ¢(T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡O(\sqrt{T})italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) regret and O~â¢(T)~ğ‘‚ğ‘‡\tilde{O}(\sqrt{T})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) CCV without any restrictive assumptions. For the first time, we answer this in the affirmative and show that a simple first-order policy can simultaneously achieve these bounds. Furthermore, in the case of strongly convex cost and convex constraint functions, the regret guarantee can be improved to Oâ¢(logâ¡T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡O(\log T)italic_O ( roman_log italic_T ) while keeping the CCV bound the same as above. We establish these results by effectively combining adaptive OCO policies as a blackbox with Lyapunov optimization - a classic tool from control theory. Surprisingly, the analysis is short and elegant.

1 Introduction

COCO arises in many applications, including online portfolio optimization with risk constraints, resource allocation in cloud computing with time-varying demands, pay-per-click online ad markets with budget constraints (Liakopoulos etÂ al., 2019), online recommendation systems, dynamic pricing, revenue management, robotics and path planning problems, and multi-armed bandits with fairness constraints (Sinha, 2024a). The necessity for revealing the constraints sequentially may also arise, e.g., in communication-limited settings, where it might be infeasible to reveal all constraints defining the feasible set at a time (e.g., combinatorial auctions). See Section 4 for an application of the COCO framework in fraud detection which involves binary classification with a highly-imbalanced dataset.

1.1 Related Work

Unconstrained OCO:

In a seminal paper, Zinkevich (2003) showed that for solving (1), the ubiquitous projected online gradient descent (OGD) policy achieves an Oâ¢(T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡O(\sqrt{T})italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) regret for convex cost functions with uniformly bounded sub-gradients. A number of follow-up papers proposed adaptive and parameter-free versions of OGD (Hazan etÂ al., 2007; Orabona and PÃ¡l, 2018). See Orabona (2019); Hazan (2022) for textbook treatments of the OCO framework and associated algorithms.

Constrained OCO (COCO): (A) Time-invariant constraints: A number of papers considered COCO with time-invariant constraints, i.e., gt,i=gi,âˆ€tsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–for-allğ‘¡g_{t,i}=g_{i},\forall\ titalic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_t (Yuan and Lamperski, 2018; Jenatton etÂ al., 2016; Mahdavi etÂ al., 2012; Yi etÂ al., 2021). These works assume that the functions gisubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–g_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are known to the policy a priori. However, they allowed the policy to remain infeasible on any round to avoid the costly projection step of the vanilla projected OGD policy. Their main objective was to design an efficient policy (avoiding the explicit projection step) with a small regret and CCV.

(B) Time-varying constraints: Solving the COCO problem when the constraint functions, i.e., gt,isubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘–g_{t,i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s, change arbitrarily with time tğ‘¡titalic_t is more challenging. In this case, except for neely2017online and georgios-cautious, most of the prior works construct some Lagrangian function and then update the primal and dual variables (yu2017online; pmlr-v70-sun17a; yi2023distributed). However, the performance bounds obtained with this approach remain suboptimal. Both neely2017online and georgios-cautious use the drift-plus-penalty (DPP) framework introduced by neely2010stochastic to solve the constrained problem under various assumptions. In particular, neely2017online proposed a DPP-based policy for COCO upon assuming the Slaterâ€™s condition, i.e., gt,iâ¢(xâ‹†)<âˆ’Î·subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœ‚g_{t,i}(x^{\star})<-\etaitalic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < - italic_Î·, for some Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0italic_Î· > 0 âˆ€i,tfor-allğ‘–ğ‘¡\forall i,tâˆ€ italic_i , italic_t. Clearly, this condition precludes the important case of non-negative constraint functions (e.g., constraint functions of the form maxâ¡(0,gtâ¢(x))0subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¥\max(0,g_{t}(x))roman_max ( 0 , italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) )). Furthermore, the bounds obtained upon assuming Slaterâ€™s condition depend inversely with the Slaterâ€™s constant Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· (usually hidden under the big-Oh notation). Since Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· could be arbitrarily small, these bounds could be arbitrarily loose. georgios-cautious extended neely2017onlineâ€™s result by considering a weaker form of the feasibility assumption without assuming Slaterâ€™s condition. Furthermore, although these DPP-based results are interesting, they have not been able to provide improved regret or CVV bounds when the cost functions ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are strongly convex because of the linearization step inherent in this approach.

In a recent paper, guo2022online considered COCO and obtained the best-known prior results without assuming Slaterâ€™s condition. However, in addition to yielding sub-optimal bounds, their policy is quite computationally intensive since it requires solving a convex optimization problem on each round. Compared to this, all policies proposed in this paper take only a single gradient-descent step and perform only one Euclidean projection on each round. Please refer to Table 1 for a brief summary of the results and Section A.5 in the Appendix for a qualitative comparison. The COCO problem has been considered in the dynamic setting as well (chen2018bandit; cao2018online; vazecocowiopt2022; liu2022simultaneously) where the benchmark xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (1) is replaced by xtâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡â‹†x_{t}^{\star}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is also allowed to change its actions over time. However, we focus our attention on achieving the optimal performance bounds for the static version. A special case of COCO is the Online Constraint Satisfaction (OCS) problem that does not involve any cost function, i.e., ft=0,âˆ€t,subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡0for-allğ‘¡f_{t}=0,\ \forall t,italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , âˆ€ italic_t , and the only object of interest is the CCV. The OCSÂ problem becomes especially interesting in the setting where the feasible set may be empty.

1.2 Our Contributions

In this paper, we consider both COCO and OCS problems and make the following contributions.

  1. 1.

    We propose an efficient first-order policy that simultaneously achieves Oâ¢(T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡O(\sqrt{T})italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) regret and Oâ¢(Tâ¢logâ¡T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡ğ‘‡O(\sqrt{T}\log T)italic_O ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG roman_log italic_T ) CCV for the COCO problem. Our result breaks the long-standing Oâ¢(T3/4)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡34O(T^{\nicefrac{{3}}{{4}}})italic_O ( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) barrier for the CCV and matches the lower bound (derived in Theorem 3, previously missing from the literature) up to a logarithmic term. For strongly convex cost functions, the regret guarantee is improved to Oâ¢(logâ¡T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡O(\log T)italic_O ( roman_log italic_T ) while keeping the CCV bound the same as above. Under an additional assumption that the regret is non-negative, we obtain a further improved logarithmic CCV bound in the strongly convex setting (see Table 1).

  2. 2.

    We additionally consider a special case of the COCO problem, called Online Constraint Satisfaction (OCS), under relaxed feasibility assumptions and obtain sub-linear CCV bounds.

  3. 3.

    On the algorithmic side, our policy simply runs an adaptive first-order OCO algorithm as a blackbox on a specially constructed convex surrogate cost function sequence. On every round, the policy needs to compute only two gradients and an Euclidean projection. This is way more efficient compared to the policies proposed in the previous works (guo2022online; neely2017online), which need to solve expensive convex optimization problems on each round while yielding sub-optimal bounds. Furthermore, in the special case of time-invariant constraints, our results yield an efficient first-order OCO policy with competitive regret and CCV bounds (mahdavi2012trading; jenatton2016adaptive; yi2021regret).

  4. 4.

    Our results are obtained by introducing a crisp and elegant potential function-based algorithmic technique for simultaneously controlling the regret and the CCV. In brief, the regret and CCV bounds are derived from a single inequality that arises from plugging in off-the-shelf adaptive regret bounds in a new regret decomposition result (Eqn.Â (6)). This new analytical technique might also be of independent interest.

  5. 5.

    Finally, in Section 4, we evaluate the practical performance of our algorithm in the online credit card fraud detection problem with a highly imbalanced dataset.

2 The Constrained OCO (COCO) Problem

The feasibility assumption distinguishes the cost functions from the constraint functions and is commonly assumed in the literature (guo2022online; neely2017online; yu2016low; yuan2018online; yi2023distributed; georgios-cautious). 2.2 Online Policy for COCO

Recall that compared to the standard OCO problem where the only objective is to minimize the Regret (hazan2022introduction), in COCO, our objective is twofold: to simultaneously control the Regret and the CCV. See Section A.2 in the Appendix for preliminaries on the OCO problem and some standard results which will be useful in our analysis. In the following, we propose a Lyapunov function-based policy that yields the optimal Regret and CCV bounds for the COCO problem. Although for simplicity, we assume that the horizon length Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is known, we can use the standard doubling trick for an unknown T.ğ‘‡T.italic_T .

2.3 Design and Analysis of the Algorithm

To simplify the analysis, we pre-process the cost and constraint functions on each round as follows.

Â Pre-processing: On every round, we first clip the negative part of the constraint function to zero by passing it through the standard ReLU unit. Then, we scale both the cost and constraint functions by a positive factor Î²,ğ›½\beta,italic_Î² , which will be determined later. In other words, we work with the pre-processed inputs f~tâ†Î²â¢ft,g~tâ†Î²â¢(gt)+.formulae-sequenceâ†subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ›½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡â†subscript~ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡\tilde{f}_{t}\leftarrow\beta f_{t},\tilde{g}_{t}\leftarrow\beta(g_{t})^{+}.over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† italic_Î² italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â† italic_Î² ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Please refer to Appendix A.6 for the proof of Theorem 2.

Remarks: The second part of the theorem is surprising because it says that when the regret is non-negative, a stronger logarithmic CCV bound holds for not necessarily strongly convex constraints. In Appendix A.7, we give example of an interesting class of adversaries, called convex adversary, for which the non-negative regret assumption holds true in the OCO setting.

2.4 Lower Bounds

We now show that under Assumptions 1, 2, and 3, the regret and the CCV of any online policy for the COCO problem for Tğ‘‡Titalic_T rounds are both lower bounded by Î©â¢(T)Î©ğ‘‡\Omega(\sqrt{T})roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) provided the problem is high-dimensional. Recall that if the constraint function gt=0,âˆ€tsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡0for-allğ‘¡g_{t}=0,\forall titalic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , âˆ€ italic_t, then the COCO problem reduces to the standard OCO problem, and Î©â¢(T)Î©ğ‘‡\Omega(\sqrt{T})roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) is a well-known regret lower bound for OCO (hazan2022introduction, Theorem 10). In this case, we trivially have CCV=0.CCV0\textrm{CCV}=0.CCV = 0 . The main challenge in proving a lower bound for COCO is simultaneously bounding both the regret and CCV. Prior work does not give any simultaneous lower bounds since the standard adversarial inputs used to derive the lower bound of hazan2022introduction do not satisfy the feasibility assumption (Assumption 3). We derive the lower bound by constructing a sequence of cost and constraint functions that satisfy Assumption 3 in a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional Euclidean box of unit diameter.

Theorem 3.

Under Assumptions 1, 2, and 3, for any choice of the horizon length Tğ‘‡Titalic_T and online policy, there exists a problem instance with dimension dâ‰¥Tğ‘‘ğ‘‡d\geq Titalic_d â‰¥ italic_T where minâ¡(RegretT,CCVT)=Î©â¢(T).subscriptRegretğ‘‡subscriptCCVğ‘‡Î©ğ‘‡\min(\textrm{Regret}_{T},\textrm{CCV}_{T})=\Omega(\sqrt{T}).roman_min ( Regret start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , CCV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) .

In high-dimensional problems where dâ‰«T,much-greater-thanğ‘‘ğ‘‡d\gg T,italic_d â‰« italic_T , the above lower bound matches with the upper bound given in Theorem 1. The proof of Theorem 3 can be found in Appendix A.4.

3 The Online Constraint Satisfaction Problem (OCS)

In this section, we study a special case of the COCO problem, which involves only constraint functions and no cost functions. In Section A.8 in the Appendix, we also establish a connection between the OCS problem and the well-studied Convex Body Chasing problem (argue2019nearly). 4 Experiments: Credit Card Fraud Detection

Classification with a highly imbalanced dataset:

We first formulate the credit card fraud detection problem in the COCO framework. Assume that we receive a sequence of dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional feature vectors {zt}tâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1\{z_{t}\}_{t\geq 1}{ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â‰¥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the corresponding binary labels {yt}tâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1\{y_{t}\}_{t\geq 1}{ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â‰¥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a sequence of credit card transactions, where each transaction can either be legitimate (label =0absent0=0= 0) or fraudulent (label =1absent1=1= 1). The problem is to predict the label y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each transaction ztsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡z_{t}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT before its true label ytâˆˆ{0,1}subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡01y_{t}\in\{0,1\}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } is revealed. Typically, legitimate transactions outnumber fraudulent transactions by orders of magnitude. Since the goal is to detect any fraudulent transactions (even at the cost of a few false alarms), maximizing the classification accuracy alone is insufficient due to the significant class imbalance. We propose the following reformulation for this problem within the COCO framework.

Formulation:

We train the model by maximizing the sum of log-likelihoods for legitimate transactions, subject to the constraint that all fraudulent transactions have a likelihood value close to 1111 (i.e., the sum of the log-likelihoods of the fraudulent transactions remains close to zero):

In our experiments, we consider the common scenario in which the likelihoods are modeled by the output of a feedforward neural network. Note that the feasibility assumption (Assumption 3) is naturally satisfied as the overparameterized neural network models are known to perfectly fit the data (belkin2019reconciling). However, in this case, the functions ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are generally non-convex.

Experiments:

We experiment with a publicly available credit card transaction dataset (dal2014learned). This highly imbalanced dataset contains only 492492492492 frauds (âˆ¼0.17%similar-toabsentpercent0.17\sim 0.17\%âˆ¼ 0.17 %) out of 284,807284807284,807284 , 807 reported transactions. Each data point has Din=30subscriptğ·in30D_{\textrm{in}}=30italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 30 features and binary labels. We choose a simple network architecture with a single hidden layer containing H=10ğ»10H=10italic_H = 10 hidden nodes and sigmoid non-linearities. Unlike previous algorithms, our algorithm is especially suitable for training neural network models as it only needs to compute the gradients (via backward pass) and evaluate the functions (via forward pass). Initially, all weights are independently sampled from a standard normal distribution. The network is then trained using Algorithm 1 on a quad-core CPU with 8 GB RAM. The projection operation corresponds to L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-normalization. The code has been publicly released (coco-code).

Results:

Given the severe class imbalance, the area under the ROC curve, which plots the True Positive Rate (TPR) against the False Positive Rate (FPR), is an appropriate metric to evaluate any prediction algorithm for this problem. By varying the hyperparameter Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», we obtain the ROC curve shown in Figure 2. The area under the ROC curve is computed to be â‰ˆ0.92absent0.92\approx 0.92â‰ˆ 0.92, which is an excellent score (cf. ideal score =1.0absent1.0=1.0= 1.0), notwithstanding the fact that, unlike the standard resampling-based techniques, the algorithm learns in an entirely online fashion starting from random initialization. Figure 2 illustrates the expected sublinear variation of CCV during one of the algorithm runs.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed efficient online policies for the COCO problem with optimal performance bounds. We also derived sublinear CCV bounds for the OCS problem under a set of relaxed assumptions. Our analysis is streamlined, leveraging Lyapunov theory and adaptive regret bounds for the standard OCO problem. In the future, exploring dynamic regret bounds and a bandit extension of the COCO problem would be interesting.

Appendix A Appendix

A.1 Discussion on Assumptions 1, 2 and 3

Assumptions 1 and 2 are standard in the online learning literature. The feasibility assumption (Assumption 3) is analogous to the realizability assumption in learning theory [pmlr-v178-hopkins22a] and is commonly used in the COCO literature [neely2017online, yu2016low, yuan2018online, yi2023distributed, georgios-cautious]. Assumption 3 requires the existence of a single admissible action xâ‹†âˆˆğ’³superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğ’³x^{\star}\in\mathcal{X}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X that satisfies the constraints in every round. Consequently, all constraint functions are required to be non-positive over a non-empty common subset. This assumption is weakened in Section 3, Assumption 4, which only requires the existence of a fixed admissible action xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that satisfies the constraints on average. Specifically, Assumption 4 requires that the sum of the constraint functions evaluated at some admissible xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over any interval of length Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is non-positive. Notably, throughout the paper, we do not assume Slaterâ€™s condition as it does not hold in many problems of interest [yu2016low]. As a result, unlike many previous works [yu2017online], our bounds are independent of Slaterâ€™s constant, which can be problem-dependent. Furthermore, we do not restrict the sign of either cost or constraint functions, allowing them to take both positive and negative values.

Similar adaptive regret bounds are known for various other online learning policies as well. For structured domains, one can use other algorithms such as AdaFTRL [orabona2018scale] which gives better regret bounds for high-dimensional problems. Furthermore, for problems with combinatorial structures, adaptive oracle-efficient algorithms, e.g., Follow-the-Perturbed-Leader (FTPL)-based policies, can be employed [abernethy2014online, Theorem 11]. Our proposed policies are agnostic to the specific online learning subroutine used for the surrogate OCO problem - what matters is that the subroutine provides adaptive regret bounds similar to (25) and (26). This flexibility allows for an immediate extension of our algorithm to a wide range of settings, such as delayed feedback [joulani2016delay] or combinatorial actions.

A.3 Online Multi-task Learning as an Instance of the OCSÂ  Problem

Consider the problem of online multi-task learning where a single model is trained to perform a number of related tasks [ruder2017overview, dekel2006online, murugesan2016adaptive]. See Figure 3 for a simplified schematic of the multi-task learning pipeline. In this setup, the action xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT naturally corresponds to the shared weight vector that specifies the common model for all tasks. The loss function for the jğ‘—jitalic_jth task on round tğ‘¡titalic_t is given by the function gt,jâ¢(â‹…),jâˆˆ[k].subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘—â‹…ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘˜g_{t,j}(\cdot),j\in[k].italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) , italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_k ] . A task is assumed to be satisfactorily completed (e.g., correct prediction in the case of classification problems) on any round if the corresponding loss is non-positive. As an example, using linear predictors for the binary classification problem, the requirement for the jğ‘—jitalic_jth task on round tğ‘¡titalic_t can be taken to be gt,jâ¢(xt)â‰¡âŸ¨zt,j,xtâŸ©â‰¤0,subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡0g_{t,j}(x_{t})\equiv\langle z_{t,j},x_{t}\rangle\leq 0,italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¡ âŸ¨ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© â‰¤ 0 , where zt,jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡ğ‘—z_{t,j}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the feature vector for the jğ‘—jitalic_jth task. The goal in multi-task learning is to sequentially update the shared weight vectors {xt}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡\{x_{t}\}_{t=1}^{T}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT so that all tasks are successfully completed. Formally, we require that the maximum cumulative loss of each task over any sub-interval grows sub-linearly. Since the weight vector is shared across the tasks, the above goal would be impossible to achieve had the tasks not been related to each other [ruder2017overview]. Theorem 4 and Theorem 5 give performance bounds for Algorithm 2 under different task-relatedness assumptions.

A.5 Comparison with Previous Works

A.5.1 neely2017online, yu2017online and georgios-cautious
